docs.lead_paragraph: A New York State report says a spike in horse fatalities at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens might have been prevented had racing authorities more closely monitored the use of prescription drugs.

headline.seo: Aqueduct Racing Officials Faulted in Horse Deaths
headline.main: Inquiry Faults Racing Officials in Horse Fatalities at Aqueduct
headline.print_headline: Inquiry Faults Racing Officials In Horse Fatalities at Aqueduct

docs.abstract: New York State investigation ordered by Gov Andrew M Cuomo reports that more than half of the 21 racehorses who had fatal breakdowns at Aqueduct Racetrack in 2012 might have been saved had racing authorities more closely monitored their health and the liberal use of prescription drugs to keep them racing; finds that veterinarians and racing officials often cared more about generating revenue for trainers, owners and racetracks than about whether horses were fit to compete.
docs.snippet: A New York State report says a spike in horse fatalities at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens might have been prevented had racing authorities more closely monitored the use of prescription drugs.

byline.original: By JOE DRAPE and WALT BOGDANICH

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though tests sometimes go awry, patients in Russia are eager to join drug trials because often they are the only way to receive modern medical care.

headline.seo: Russians Eagerly Participating in Medical Experiments, Despite Risks
headline.main: Russians Eagerly Participate in Medical Experiments, Despite Risks

docs.abstract: Russian regulators, doctors and even many patients are increasingly embracing any chance they can get to take part in medical experiments; even though tests sometimes go awry, and side effects can be brutal, patients are eager to join drug trials because often they are the only way to receive modern medical care.
docs.snippet: Even though tests sometimes go awry, patients in Russia are eager to join drug trials because often they are the only way to receive modern medical care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Drugs such as Abilify and Seroquel have been around for a long time, but until recently they were not widely used.

headline.seo: A Call for Caution in the Use of Antipsychotic Drugs
headline.main: A Call for Caution on Antipsychotic Drugs
headline.print_headline: A Call for Caution on Antipsychotic Drugs

docs.abstract: Dr Richard A Freidman essay urges caution in prescribing powerful anti-psychotic drugs, which have the potential for serious adverse side effects; notes that the number of annual prescriptions of such drugs has risen to 54 million in 2011 from 28 million in 2001, with an increase in usage among young people and patients with comparatively minor disorders.
docs.snippet: Drugs such as Abilify and Seroquel have been around for a long time, but until recently they were not widely used.

docs.lead_paragraph: Required screening for participation in athletics or other activities can begin as early as middle school, confusing students and stirring objections from parents.

headline.seo: Even Some Middle Schools Now Test for Drugs
headline.main: Middle Schools Add a Team Rule: Get a Drug Test
headline.print_headline: Middle Schools Add Team Rule: Get a Drug Test

docs.abstract: Children in grades as low as middle school are being told that drug testing is required to play sports or participate in extracurricular activities, and mandate is confounding students and stirring objections from parents and proponents of civil liberties; some coaches, teachers and school administrators defend program saying that drug testing serves as a deterrent to students encountering drugs of all kinds.
docs.snippet: Required screening for participation in athletics or other activities can begin as early as middle school, confusing students and stirring objections from parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: Horse-racing veterinarians are both doctor and drugstore; the more drugs they prescribe, the more money they make.

headline.seo: At the Track, Racing Economics Collide With Veterinarians’ Oath
headline.main: At the Track, Racing Economics Collide With Veterinarians’ Oath
headline.print_headline: At Racetrack, Economic Pressures Overpower Veterinarians’ Oath

docs.abstract: Dozens of interviews conducted by the New York Times reveal that racetrack veterinarians prioritize drug regimens that keep horses racing and winning rather than treating soreness or injury through less aggressive means; such veterinarians sell the drugs they prescribe, giving them a powerful financial incentive to keep horses on heavy regimens (Series: Breakdown).
docs.snippet: Horse-racing veterinarians are both doctor and drugstore; the more drugs they prescribe, the more money they make.

byline.contributor: Dara Miles, Laura Dodd and Rebecca Teitel contributed reporting.
byline.original: By WALT BOGDANICH, JOE DRAPE and REBECCA R. RUIZ
